31bee109-7547-4e08-887d-a257907a28fe.content: {It is false that a perfectly aligned soul with harmful ideologies is truly virtuous}, {Rational thought in a truly virtuous soul inherently rejects harmful ideologies}, {Virtue as inner harmony includes inherently moral rational values}

7e8c0d43-ab85-47cf-b730-4436464e0488.content: {Moral education is a supplementary assumption required for the rational part to develop sound values}, {With moral education, the rational part aligns the soul towards good, preventing harmful acts}, {Inner harmony needs moral guidance to ensure virtue is realized}

b5cbc006-ee42-48db-bef0-ce02a4fec542.content: {Virtue is reasonable alignment}, {Reasonable alignment is the balance of different parts of the soul}, {The rational part of the soul should guide, but not dominate, other parts}

d0d9ef01-8fd9-487f-bb99-52e1d27a460d.content: {Virtue is dynamic equilibrium}, {Dynamic equilibrium involves continuous adjustment of the soul's parts}, {The rational part of the soul must remain flexible to achieve equilibrium}

f23d0708-93c9-4014-9840-2f6e7db46dc2.content: {Virtue is pluralistic harmony}, {Pluralistic harmony is the collaboration of various parts of the soul}, {Each part of the soul has an important role in achieving harmony}

1d5a50c8-932e-4404-92f4-7166ad88f796.content: {Virtue is ethical balance}, {Ethical balance involves navigating between competing values}, {The rational part of the soul must balance ethical considerations with emotional responses}

0ee37f1d-8d24-4b95-9125-6c54e4d3b792.content: {Virtue is responsive coordination}, {Responsive coordination involves adjusting to circumstances}, {The rational part of the soul should adapt to ensure coordination}

538d977c-ace2-42aa-91e9-1f69d09971fa.content: {Virtue is rational support}, {Rational support is the integration of the soul's parts}, {The rational part of the soul supports other parts in collaborative action}

b5acee20-24fe-45a8-8210-740e4be24164.content: {Inner harmony does not imply a lack of conflicting impulses but rather the prioritization of the rational part.}, {Virtue as inner harmony involves managing conflicts through rational governance.}, {Ethical dilemmas are instances where rational governance must operate amidst competing desires or values.}, {Maintaining virtue does not necessitate the absence of conflict but rather its rational resolution.}

065b0573-3b6c-4e04-8805-0803a3eaf7a7.summary: Rejecting the necessity to compromise harmony
065b0573-3b6c-4e04-8805-0803a3eaf7a7.content: {It is false that handling ethical dilemmas inherently compromises inner harmony.}, {Inner harmony involves aligning the soul towards rational goals even when faced with dilemmas.}, {Rational deliberation itself is a manifestation of inner harmony.}, {The belief that dilemmas necessitate compromising harmony misunderstands the flexibility of rational governance.}

ceb62b87-3613-4711-bcb0-4b89758f98ad.content: {Inner harmony is dynamic and adapts to changing ethical circumstances.}, {Incorporating dynamic harmony allows for the realignment of the soul's parts in response to ethical challenges.}, {Dynamic harmony accommodates rational reassessment and reprioritization during dilemmas.}, {Ethical dilemmas serve as opportunities to reinforce rather than disrupt inner harmony.}

85b28b53-5819-4b7e-894b-1a13593b9bb8.content: {Virtue is the coordination of rational and emotional parts}, {Rational part and emotional parts can work together toward virtuous actions}, {Rational guidance integrates emotional motivations without strict control}

a9833ad8-324b-4867-97cb-28dcfba5086d.content: {Virtue is the balance between rational decision-making and emotional influences}, {Rational decisions are informed by emotional insights}, {Virtuous actions arise when emotions and rationality equally contribute}

2b30e7ff-f4e4-4b3a-ab6c-233a45e50078.content: {Virtue results from achieving reflective equilibrium between rational and emotional parts}, {Reflective equilibrium involves adjusting beliefs until coherence is achieved}, {Virtuous action is the result of equilibrium between beliefs and emotions}

43779348-9112-46e6-8dc9-6ebcf5458e87.content: {Virtue is emotional resonance aligning with rational ideals}, {Emotions resonate with rational ideals to guide actions}, {Harmonious action occurs when emotional resonance supports rational goals}

297884fc-6436-4c94-a7e5-73b8fdc2ec09.content: {Virtue results from dynamic alignment of soul's parts}, {Emotion and reason dynamically align to guide virtuous actions}, {Alignment does not require fixed governance by rationality}

874bd400-2f13-4ee1-b0e4-96bcae2ab904.summary: Distinguishing rational governance from emotional influence
874bd400-2f13-4ee1-b0e4-96bcae2ab904.content: {There is a distinction between rational governance and emotional influence in virtue}, {Virtue as inner harmony is a theory about alignment, which involves a hierarchy where the rational part governs}, {Emotional parts influencing actions does not undermine virtue as inner harmony, since influence is compatible with governance}, {Even strong emotional impulses can act in accordance with rational governance without formal alignment compromising inner harmony}

0cb62c63-1269-4f45-a320-3cb05e7d542b.summary: Rejecting emotion-led virtuous actions as exceptions
0cb62c63-1269-4f45-a320-3cb05e7d542b.content: {It is false that emotions can independently guide virtue without alignment with the rational part}, {Instances where emotions seem to guide virtuous actions are cases where alignment with rational governance exists implicitly}, {Inner harmony is crucial for sustained virtuous behavior, regardless of instances of perceived emotional independence}

f17e7134-b425-4651-978e-29417acb83e5.summary: Supplementary assumption of occasional spontaneous harmony
f17e7134-b425-4651-978e-29417acb83e5.content: {Occasional spontaneous harmony can exist between emotions and rational guidance}, {Spontaneous alignment does not require continuous governance by the rational part at every moment to maintain inner harmony}, {Virtue as inner harmony allows for temporary autonomous actions by emotions provided they eventually align back with rational governance}

e2e6eb5f-d409-4364-b973-10049d04461d.content: The system was unable to generate a synthesis from this thesis-antithesis pair.

935fbdc3-f4bf-44f0-ba41-88394af0aca8.content: {Virtue is the consistent performance of just actions}, {Just actions are those that align with moral principles}, {The rational part of the soul must discern and apply these moral principles}

303c6a75-cbcf-4c95-b88e-06aac2789022.content: {Virtue involves achieving balance among competing demands of the soul}, {Moral judgment is necessary to resolve conflicts among the parts of the soul}, {The rational part of the soul must use judgment to harmonize competing demands}

f6c7488a-0e96-4e2f-91a1-34ebbdabddd7.content: {Virtue consists in the rational guidance of the soul}, {Rational guidance requires understanding of moral complexities}, {The rational part of the soul is responsible for interpreting and negotiating moral complexities}

fa3b840d-59b1-4f09-bd73-fa4853131cf8.content: {Virtue requires moral wisdom that extends beyond inner harmony}, {Moral wisdom involves understanding and resolving moral dilemmas}, {The rational part of the soul develops wisdom through experience and reflection}

f3cc26b9-a0cd-48ec-8b74-48961629200b.content: {Virtue is the excellence of each part of the soul functioning properly}, {Excellence is defined by the appropriate role and function of each part}, {The rational part of the soul coordinates the functioning of the whole soul}

f4590646-6757-43e0-904e-728a1de093da.summary: Clarifying inner harmony's role in moral complexity
f4590646-6757-43e0-904e-728a1de093da.content: {Inner harmony provides a stable foundation to navigate moral complexities.}, {Inner harmony allows for adaptability in complex moral situations through its principle of rational governance.}, {The rational part of the soul can negotiate and balance the needs of other soul parts even in complex cases.}, {Complex moral scenarios do not necessarily exceed the capacity of inner harmony if the rational governance is flexible.}

441ade9d-b047-454d-ab51-5847c5e2c588.summary: Reaffirming the sufficiency of inner harmony
441ade9d-b047-454d-ab51-5847c5e2c588.content: {Inner harmony encompasses more than simple harmony, implying depth sufficient for complex moral reasoning.}, {The rational part’s governance involves continuous negotiation and adaptation of the soul’s parts to specific contexts.}, {Inner harmony’s structure inherently supports the nuanced negotiation required in moral complexities.}, {Virtue, as inner harmony, transforms to suit diverse moral circumstances through deep alignment processes.}

81cab5e6-8a6e-4af8-8234-923593a68217.content: {Inner harmony is supplemented by a notion of moral discernment, enhancing its capacity to handle complexities.}, {The rational part of the soul can exercise discernment in complex moral situations, consistent with maintaining harmony.}, {Moral discernment acts as a practical supplement that allows inner harmony to be effectively applied in nuanced cases.}, {Inner harmony remains the core of virtue while integrating moral discernment for complex contexts.}

6145e4b7-44d3-4453-8769-f046c693d91a.summary: Virtue as Individual Disposition Within Social Context
6145e4b7-44d3-4453-8769-f046c693d91a.content: {Virtue is primarily an individual disposition}, {Virtues can be influenced and enhanced by participation in social practices}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}

d39a192e-347b-4c44-80c2-f5d33142f5fd.content: {Virtue emerges from a combination of individual tendencies and contextual interactions}, {Social contexts provide opportunities for virtuous actions}, {Individuals can possess virtues through personal reflection and interaction with their environment}

2b932dbd-8fe9-4211-afc2-8f2000f67b7d.content: {Virtue is an innate potentiality that can be actualized}, {Social practices provide one pathway to actualize virtues}, {Individuals can actualize virtues independently through personal efforts and reflection}

7c79ae2f-92cd-404a-a844-63e650091c9b.content: {Virtue is an intrinsic aspect of one's character}, {Character can be influenced by social practices but is fundamentally independent}, {Virtues are expressed through both social and solitary actions}

3661495a-abbc-495d-af31-e661dbdf7835.content: {Virtue involves adapting characteristics to circumstances}, {Social practices offer contexts for adaptation}, {Virtue is also adaptable in the absence of social practices}

58c68279-b0d1-4d9b-8200-2d47c6a0ee96.content: {Virtue is a rational achievement pursued by individuals}, {Social practices provide frameworks for understanding virtues}, {Individuals can rationally develop virtues without direct social practice involvement}

1245ee1c-5e30-428f-9ad7-c8c93a754f6c.summary: Distinguishing between social and personal virtue development
1245ee1c-5e30-428f-9ad7-c8c93a754f6c.content: {There is a distinction between social and personal contexts for developing virtue}, {Virtue as a social practice emphasizes shared activities, but personal experiences can also contribute to virtue}, {Isolated individuals might develop virtue through personal reflection and moral reasoning, independent of social practices}

dd5e2024-8dc1-4e39-b817-68494d8de0f6.summary: Rejecting the necessity of societal interaction for virtue
dd5e2024-8dc1-4e39-b817-68494d8de0f6.content: {The claim that virtues can only develop through social interactions is false}, {An individual can internalize virtuous traits without society by engaging in personal ethical deliberation}, {Virtuous traits such as honesty and courage can emerge from individual contexts without adhering to social norms}

c41f1966-38e2-4778-a459-8cfcaa8297d9.summary: Discussing imitative and solitary virtue acquisition
c41f1966-38e2-4778-a459-8cfcaa8297d9.content: {Virtue includes elements of imitation and self-reflection}, {Through contemplation and personal experience, individuals can imitate observed virtuous behaviors even in isolation}, {Solitary meditation on ethical principles can lead to the identification and adoption of virtuous behaviors}

dccd7102-a08a-4ffb-b1ef-700cada06bf6.summary: Supplementing the social practice view with innate moral sense
dccd7102-a08a-4ffb-b1ef-700cada06bf6.content: {Individuals may possess an innate moral sense that guides the development of virtue}, {This innate moral sense can operate independently of social practices}, {Even while isolated, individuals can develop virtues by tapping into this innate moral faculty, complementing the role of social practices}

b0ca9171-ec2b-4eac-9d43-7bb4c322d51b.content: {Virtue is integral to human flourishing}, {Human flourishing is a universal goal across cultures}, {Virtues facilitate the achievement of this universal human flourishing}

a12184df-9d9b-4bd7-8a46-73d10cc77b2a.content: {Virtue is an intrinsic goodness}, {Intrinsic goodness is not contingent on cultural practices}, {Virtues are recognized as good independently of cultural norms}

2a5811c2-01fb-430d-a473-49ecd2b2d5c6.content: {Virtue consists of universal human capacities}, {Human capacities are inherent to human beings regardless of culture}, {Virtues develop as these inherent capacities are nurtured and expressed}

72fd5962-0848-480d-9e7c-b7ae2b87612f.content: {Virtue arises from the harmony of rationality and emotion}, {Rationality and emotion are fundamental aspects of human life not tied to a specific culture}, {Virtues are expressions of balanced rational capacities and emotions}

245710ab-bf97-4062-aaff-b67ecf1dc515.content: {Virtue is about moral functionality across diverse environments}, {Moral functionality is not restricted to any specific cultural practice}, {Virtues are adaptive responses to moral challenges across contexts}

9b2effc7-6d99-42af-9a0b-afd5f1cc4ea1.summary: Virtue as Moral Constraints and Abilities
9b2effc7-6d99-42af-9a0b-afd5f1cc4ea1.content: {Virtue depends on moral constraints and abilities inherent in humans}, {Moral constraints and abilities transcend specific cultural practices}, {Virtues emerge from innate human constraints and abilities in moral contexts}

7cc9a1c3-3df6-479b-a8d5-9fb88af9c932.summary: Distinguishing universal appreciation from practice-based development
7cc9a1c3-3df6-479b-a8d5-9fb88af9c932.content: {There is a distinction between the universal appreciation of virtues and their development through social practices}, {Virtues such as honesty and compassion can be universally appreciated without necessitating a universal practice for their development}, {The development of virtues through culturally specific practices does not preclude their universal recognition or appreciation}, {The apparent contradiction arises from conflating the recognition of virtues with their developmental contexts}

a91959da-963d-4b69-a994-0ed03d2aa752.summary: Rejecting the necessity of uniform cultural norms
a91959da-963d-4b69-a994-0ed03d2aa752.content: {It is false that the development of virtues necessarily requires uniform cultural norms}, {The existence of virtues like honesty across cultures indicates convergent evolution through diverse practices rather than identical norms}, {Virtue as a social practice accounts for different forms of practice leading to similar virtues}, {Cultural variation enriches rather than contradicts the practice-based development of virtues}

e898769d-54c8-4348-8c9f-48abe3778aba.summary: Explaining the universal traits through evolutionary psychology
e898769d-54c8-4348-8c9f-48abe3778aba.content: {Some virtues might be universally appreciated due to evolutionary psychological traits common in humans}, {Participation in social practices is influenced by underlying psychological factors that favor certain virtues}, {The appreciation of certain virtues across cultures may result from shared evolutionary origins rather than identical social practices}, {The objection loses force when considering evolutionary predispositions as supplementary to social practices}

933ce292-bb74-4f9c-a3c0-1cc790263717.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices involve rules as integral components}, {Virtues develop through adherence to these rules in practice}

2c546c77-c2df-4f06-a05b-6f8e085403ce.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices involve roles with specific obligations}, {Virtues develop through fulfilling the responsibilities of these roles within practices}

e504c54a-c4c5-4043-96ff-d54479b94195.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are based on shared understandings of appropriate behavior}, {Virtues develop as individuals internalize these communal understandings}

a96c9b3c-7bb5-4a4c-8583-ff58340e948e.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are constituted by moral standards}, {Virtues develop by internalizing and upholding these standards through practice}

ebcfc792-8fdf-465a-a07d-7acbbaea1638.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are rooted in traditions which include normative expectations}, {Virtues develop by engaging with and preserving these traditions}

77232a91-4689-4431-a7ca-d30c89092cb6.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices involve guided participation toward normative goals}, {Virtues develop as one increasingly meets these goals through practice}

7f8e7749-3318-44f1-b619-f5c541bcb445.content: {Recreational sports can be distinguished from other social practices by their primary focus on enjoyment rather than normativity.}, {Normative activities require rules or standards that guide and assess participant behavior, beyond just participation or enjoyment.}, {Virtue develops specifically through those social practices that bear normative weight, not simply any shared activity.}

22a555ff-588a-48c0-8b1e-de9bd9eee9b9.summary: Rejecting the claim that recreational activities lack normativity
22a555ff-588a-48c0-8b1e-de9bd9eee9b9.content: {It is false that recreational sports entirely lack normativity; they often involve implicit rules and expectations.}, {Even activities pursued for enjoyment can involve an understanding of unwritten standards of conduct shared among participants.}, {Participation in recreational sports can still lead to the development of virtues when these normative aspects are engaged.}

fcd7e0eb-cadb-48ae-a966-eeb5914e18d0.summary: Understanding normativity through implicit social codes
fcd7e0eb-cadb-48ae-a966-eeb5914e18d0.content: {Social practices contain implicit social codes that provide a normative framework.}, {Participation in any shared activity often involves adherence to understood social codes, which are normative in nature.}, {The presence of these implicit codes ensures that even seemingly non-normative activities can foster virtues.}

9e458669-e25e-470d-8cc5-ad818a725ada.summary: Supplementing with the concept of contextual normativity
9e458669-e25e-470d-8cc5-ad818a725ada.content: {Normative elements in social practices can vary based on context and participants' objectives.}, {What seems non-normative in one context can acquire normative value in another when it aligns with the goals of virtue development.}, {Virtue as a social practice involves recognizing how the context imbues activities with normative significance.}

9dcfdd97-939b-4b92-9889-1ecdbcc5eda7.content: {Virtue is an activity of the rational soul}, {The rational soul guides actions according to reason}, {Acting according to reason leads to the development of virtue}

0c8f0e50-3236-4201-9723-e8ed42f8ed57.content: {Virtue is an ethical commitment}, {Ethical commitments are long-term engagements to moral values}, {Engagement in moral values fosters virtue}

a4011992-3e87-4f5b-886d-065da8231567.content: {Virtues and vices arise from different aspects of a single social practice.}, {The elements of a social practice that promote virtues can be separated from those that encourage vices.}, {The objection conflates distinct components within a social practice.}, {This distinction preserves the theory by showing that virtues are linked to certain normative components that are separate from those that promote vices.}

86340006-b736-42ad-9b16-e0f8c99c2769.content: {Individual choice plays a crucial role in determining whether one develops virtue or vice within a social practice.}, {Social practices provide the framework, but personal decisions shape whether virtues or vices develop.}, {Acknowledging the role of individual choice allows the original theory to account for the emergence of vice without contradicting the development of virtue.}

a84e7ab9-a81a-40e8-bd10-e72c54a9d8eb.summary: Virtue as Individual Commitment to Norms

35865859-fa03-4f8e-8ebb-8d16c660445e.content: {There is a distinction between virtues developed collectively and virtues developed individually}, {Virtue as social practice refers specifically to the collective development of virtues}, {Solitary ethical conviction can develop virtues in an individual manner}, {Collective social practices are not necessary for all forms of virtue development}, {The objection confuses the collective aspect of social practices with the possibility of individual virtue development}

8010cd70-a88c-4fda-849b-4ca154fa4343.content: {Virtues can be developed both socially and individually}, {Individual virtue formation is a supplementary process to social practices}, {The theory of virtue as social practice allows for individual development when social engagement is limited}, {The supplementary assumption of individual development addresses the objection}, {The coexistence of social and individual virtue development explains the existence of virtuous solitude}

030acdf8-f6f0-4109-ae9e-0c62c10ad10b.content: {Virtues are informed by social practices}, {Individuals cultivate virtues through internal reflection}, {Virtue development involves both social context and personal effort}

60f77a6a-9f82-4b25-abb1-58fcfc16d289.content: {Virtue is based on social practices compatible with individual reflection}, {Social practices provide a framework for virtue}, {Individual reflection and authenticity play crucial roles in virtuous development}

1ee7d77d-98f1-4f74-a5d6-a0a44dedb7c8.content: {There are individual virtues that can develop outside structured social practices.}, {Historical examples of virtuous individuals may reflect practices that are not formalized or recognized.}, {Virtues can arise through individual reflection and inner development alongside social engagement.}

36de271f-b345-49c4-bf29-e139d6485688.content: {Social practice is only one component in the development of virtue.}, {Virtue can develop through both social interaction and personal reflection and choice.}, {The role of social practices is emphasized but does not exclude internal processes.}

c16a9151-eadd-47c0-8031-6e106d6028be.content: {Virtue development involves a combination of social interaction and personal growth.}, {Social practices provide a framework, but individual insight and commitment also play crucial roles.}, {The framework of virtue as a social practice allows for personal contributions and choices.}

98d22ea1-5604-427b-810a-d4c4446ecccc.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues develop through participation in these practices}, {Virtuous practices are those that inherently promote well-being and prevent harm}

2ffe42f1-65ac-4e92-9579-94fae1394704.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues develop through participation in these practices}, {Participants in virtuous practices reflect critically on the outcomes of these practices to ensure they do not cause harm}

0caef07f-948d-4c50-acd2-3c5a6468d1cf.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues develop through participation in these practices}, {Virtuous practices are those that include mechanisms for correcting harm when it occurs}

b15145b4-6eba-454b-998b-570e65e431a7.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues develop through participation in these practices}, {Virtuous practices are those whose guiding principles are universalizable and do not lead to harm when applied broadly}

a8729f84-4f33-4094-bbc1-4f9e2b12fbf2.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues develop through participation in these practices}, {Virtuous practices are evaluated in the context of their specific outcomes and adjusted to prevent harm}

abbc7305-2c71-4a29-a12d-0871a22d3adc.summary: Distinction between social practices and inherently virtuous practices
abbc7305-2c71-4a29-a12d-0871a22d3adc.content: {There is a distinction between social practices and inherently virtuous practices}, {Virtues as social practices are idealized versions that aim at the good}, {Not all social practices qualify as virtues if they result in harm}, {A practice is only considered virtuous when they align with broader moral standards that promote good and avoid harm}

3152093a-ba22-4439-bbd9-5b62d8d61281.summary: Rejecting the equivalence of all social practices with virtues
3152093a-ba22-4439-bbd9-5b62d8d61281.content: {Not all social practices are inherently virtuous}, {The claim that all practices followed within a society are virtuous is false}, {Virtues, being normative, must be critically assessed against criteria of goodness}, {Harmful practices fail these criteria and should not be deemed virtuous}

790059f5-bf89-4f6e-a267-21c1361b5698.summary: Supplementary assumption on the role of moral reflection
790059f5-bf89-4f6e-a267-21c1361b5698.content: {Moral reflection is a necessary component of defining virtues}, {Social practices are subject to moral reflection and critique}, {Virtues require ongoing evaluation to ensure they do not result in harm}, {Incorporating moral reflection allows for the evolution of practices to align more closely with ideals of virtue}

1c361705-3ec2-41ff-9e6d-ecf604cb8a86.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Practitioners must reflectively endorse the value of practices}, {Virtues develop through practices that practitioners have reflectively endorsed as valuable}

2574a26f-8c86-40ac-8687-8a24b40b8c57.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues are identified by their role in promoting human flourishing}, {Virtues develop through participation in practices that contribute to human flourishing}

edc34bbe-20d7-4a50-8908-3c6522a135ee.summary: Virtue as Participation in Ethically Governing Practices
edc34bbe-20d7-4a50-8908-3c6522a135ee.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues require participation in practices governed by ethical norms}, {Virtues develop through ethical governance of practices}

28316ba2-412e-4418-9fe0-0a8c156ca312.content: {Virtue is a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtue emerges from activities aligned with a consensus-based moral framework}, {Virtues develop through participation in practices reflecting moral consensus}

fcc72baa-6222-41b2-b67a-83e32e4beb7b.content: {There is a distinction between social practices and moral virtues}, {Virtue as a social practice emphasizes moral dimensions within shared practices}, {Not all shared social practices are necessarily virtuous}, {Virtues develop specifically through morally oriented social practices, not merely any normative activity}

4ce9518f-9867-43b0-a2ff-862e7471bab1.content: {It is false that non-moral normative activities like gossiping fit the definition of virtue}, {Virtue inherently involves moral commitments that transcend simple normativity}, {Social practices that lead to virtue must inherently align with moral conduct}, {Gossiping, while normative, does not develop virtue due to its lack of moral grounding}

a1b95bb0-b09e-431a-817a-c38acd9ebf62.summary: Supplementary assumption of a moral criterion for social practices
a1b95bb0-b09e-431a-817a-c38acd9ebf62.content: {The concept of virtue via social practice requires a supplementary moral criterion}, {Social practices are only contributors to virtue if they adhere to moral principles}, {The development of virtues relies on practices that are both normative and moral}, {Normative activities without a moral basis do not qualify as sources of virtue}

d398e080-16ec-4f48-ae58-2291ef91c486.summary: Virtue as Innate Traits and Social Practices
d398e080-16ec-4f48-ae58-2291ef91c486.content: {Virtue is partially an innate trait}, {Virtue is also a social practice}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtues develop through participation in these practices}, {Innate traits provide a basic capacity for virtue that social practices enhance}

d5d8becb-4967-4d4a-847c-484fe1d8e09d.summary: Virtue as Dispositions Enhanced by Practice
d5d8becb-4967-4d4a-847c-484fe1d8e09d.content: {Virtue is a disposition inherent in individuals}, {These dispositions can be enhanced through social practices}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Virtue-like dispositions are observable in children, indicating some innate aspect}, {Participating in social practices strengthens and refines inherent dispositions}

7fbe689e-c403-4862-a275-304b172d40e2.summary: Virtue as a Dual Source Model
7fbe689e-c403-4862-a275-304b172d40e2.content: {Virtue has dual sources: innate traits and social practices}, {Innate traits provide a potential for virtuous behavior}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities that cultivate virtues}, {Virtues are actualized through a combination of innate predispositions and experiences within social practices}

836d9454-378f-45e7-9903-b40801bb8653.summary: Virtue as Early Instincts and Social Cultivation
836d9454-378f-45e7-9903-b40801bb8653.content: {Virtue is rooted in early instincts observable in young children}, {Virtue is further cultivated through social practices}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities}, {Early instinctual behaviors provide a foundational basis for virtue}, {The cultivation of virtues is enhanced by engagement in social practices}

342c6b03-ede5-4e1e-b2c0-ed14ae47673f.content: {Virtue results from biocultural development combining biological and cultural influences}, {Biological predispositions include early virtuous instincts}, {Cultural influences are shaped through social practices}, {Social practices are shared, normative activities that enhance virtues}, {Virtue is the product of interacting biological and cultural factors}

ff4177a3-3bd4-4216-8e42-8ee2e31d771d.summary: Distinguishing between initial predispositions and full virtues
ff4177a3-3bd4-4216-8e42-8ee2e31d771d.content: {There is a distinction between initial virtuous predispositions and fully developed virtues}, {Virtue as a social practice is about the development and refinement of virtues rather than initial predispositions}, {Children's early virtuous traits can be seen as predispositions that require social practices for full realization}, {The existence of virtue-like behavior in children does not refute the necessity of social practices in developing these traits into full virtues}

a742b324-17b6-4164-a986-0e6643ea22f3.summary: Rejection of the role of innate traits in defining virtue
a742b324-17b6-4164-a986-0e6643ea22f3.content: {The presence of innate predispositions does not equate to having virtue}, {Virtues require active engagement and refinement through participation in social practices}, {What may appear as innate virtuous behavior in children is merely a rudimentary potential that requires cultivation through social contexts}, {Virtue entails a level of understanding and commitment that mere innate tendencies lack without social practice}

bd92b52a-01d5-4321-a159-c0cf08e0be12.summary: Supplementing with the assumption of early social engagement
bd92b52a-01d5-4321-a159-c0cf08e0be12.content: {Even young children are engaged in social practices from an early age}, {Early engagement in familial and social interactions constitutes the beginning of social practices}, {Virtuous traits in children are seen as the result of early social engagement rather than innate characteristics solely}, {The development of virtues is supported by early participation in immediate social environments}

8c536bd4-8ee2-42b5-a088-996a2c9c98b7.content: {Virtue is a quality of internal character}, {Internal character can develop in isolation}, {Virtues do not require participation in social practices}

ae8b90e6-d226-403d-abbe-067be1255a9b.content: {Virtue is a disposition to act in certain ways}, {Dispositions can exist without social practices}, {Virtues entail certain responses irrespective of external activities}

cc6817e2-fd0c-4ea8-99c6-7a92cdd44a54.content: {Virtue is a process of personal development}, {Personal development can occur without social interaction}, {Virtues are manifested through personal growth over time}

84cd5d3d-3192-475e-a2fc-3492d4ba3747.content: {Virtue consists of universal traits}, {Universal traits do not require social confirmation}, {Virtues are recognizable across different contexts}

0efed567-dbe2-4fbd-bae8-88188acea73e.content: {Virtue is an intrinsic value within individuals}, {Intrinsic values are not dependent on external factors}, {Virtues are valuable irrespective of social practices}

7d3f1eba-497f-4206-b3b6-5a72d87c8cc9.summary: Distinguishing social origin of virtue from its current practice
7d3f1eba-497f-4206-b3b6-5a72d87c8cc9.content: {There is a distinction between the origin of virtue and its current practice}, {Virtues can originate in social practices but be maintained and developed individually}, {An individual can appropriate virtues initially gained from social interactions and continue to cultivate them in solitude}, {The intuition that solitary individuals cannot be virtuous is mistaken if they initially developed these virtues socially}

d4388c1b-0e53-4527-b2c3-a70e6209e414.summary: Distinguishing between active participation and internalized practices
d4388c1b-0e53-4527-b2c3-a70e6209e414.content: {There is a distinction between active participation in social practices and internalization of these practices}, {Virtue does not require ongoing active cooperation; it requires internalized normative principles}, {A solitary individual may maintain and develop virtues by relying on internalized social norms}, {The objection assumes a misconception that active participation is necessary for virtue upkeep}

959b2ead-f47c-4048-b289-127566e04e58.summary: Relying on a supplementary assumption of past exposure
959b2ead-f47c-4048-b289-127566e04e58.content: {The development of virtues requires past exposure to social practices}, {Individuals who have previously engaged in social practices can sustain and reflect upon these virtues in isolation}, {This assumption allows virtues to remain tied to social practice while accommodating isolated development}, {The belief that isolated individuals cannot be virtuous ignores their past social engagements}

183115c1-eee2-4580-8517-0bbc54ccba73.summary: Rejection of the assumption that recognition is necessary
183115c1-eee2-4580-8517-0bbc54ccba73.content: {It is false that recognition by others is necessary for someone to be considered virtuous}, {Virtue rests on adherence to normative standards, not societal acknowledgment}, {A hermit may satisfy these standards without external validation}, {The objection relies on an incorrect assumption that public acknowledgment is essential to virtue}

55086436-05e1-4998-b086-6171605adf84.summary: Virtue as Moral Sentiment and Reason
55086436-05e1-4998-b086-6171605adf84.content: {Virtue is a combination of moral sentiment and rational thought}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Rational thought is necessary for evaluating and acting upon moral sentiments}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments and developing rational thinking}

57b00b7e-1eaa-49b7-9e6e-8af94affcb30.summary: Virtue as Moral Sentiment with Active Engagement
57b00b7e-1eaa-49b7-9e6e-8af94affcb30.content: {Virtue requires moral sentiments that prompt emotional responses}, {Virtue requires active engagement with moral reasoning}, {Moral sentiments provide the motivational foundation for virtuous action}, {Active engagement in reasoning ensures alignment of sentiments with moral principles}

1ced57f4-2856-49b0-aed8-eb87dae5b967.content: {Virtue is best understood through a dual-process theory incorporating both feeling and thought}, {Moral sentiments operate as intuitive guides for action}, {Rational deliberation refines and corrects these moral sentiments}, {Virtues emerge from the interplay between intuitive sentiments and reflective reasoning}

dc63dd69-5d40-4338-8405-83d500ee7606.summary: Virtue as Sentiments and Rational Evaluations
dc63dd69-5d40-4338-8405-83d500ee7606.content: {Virtue involves moral sentiments as initial triggers for concern}, {Rational evaluations are necessary to determine appropriate moral actions}, {Virtues are developed through the interaction between moral sentiments and rational evaluations}, {Moral maturity enhances both the sensitivity of sentiments and the acuity of rational evaluations}

187194a0-8c9a-480b-aae6-2cd31de7e13f.content: {There is a distinction between the sentimental and rational components of virtue}, {Virtue as moral sentiment focuses on the sentimental component of virtue}, {The rational component of virtue involves reasoning and decision-making, which can operate alongside moral sentiments}, {The objection confuses the sentimental component of virtue with virtue in its entirety}

66999ddb-cbe1-4bde-9479-430af1d6c36d.summary: Rejecting the requirement for reasoning in every virtuous act
66999ddb-cbe1-4bde-9479-430af1d6c36d.content: {It is false that reasoning is necessary for all virtuous acts}, {Virtue as moral sentiment does not require active reasoning in every instance to be considered virtuous}, {A feeling of compassion can itself be virtuous even without explicit reasoning about action}

b6634ef0-6c7c-483d-a3a5-564775584194.content: {Virtue consists of different aspects, one of which is moral sentiment and another is reasoning}, {In different contexts, either the moral sentiment or reasoning may be more prominent}, {Acknowledging the varying dominance of moral sentiments and reasoning allows for both elements to contribute to virtue}

cffecc60-233c-4593-91c4-2bb26c090945.content: {Practical wisdom is an assumed supplement to moral sentiment in virtue}, {Practical wisdom provides the reasoning and decision-making component that integrates with moral sentiment}, {With practical wisdom as a supplement, moral sentiment can sufficiently underpin virtue}

ef6b0430-adb7-4c14-b8de-e2ba4e3858f3.content: {Virtue is a combination of moral sentiment and reason}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Reason is a necessary guide for moral actions affected by emotions}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing both moral sentiments and reason}

e373b01d-27ff-4524-adef-7bc9b00a5276.content: {Virtue is moral sentiment informed by reason}, {Moral sentiments are feelings subject to rational evaluation}, {Rational analysis refines and informs the expression of moral sentiments}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing sentiments and subjecting them to rational scrutiny}

9865fa87-f4c2-439c-969a-3108d08d02ff.summary: Virtue as Sentiment Under Rational Control
9865fa87-f4c2-439c-969a-3108d08d02ff.content: {Virtue is moral sentiment under rational control}, {Feelings guide moral actions when directed by reason}, {Rational oversight ensures moral sentiments align with ethical principles}, {Virtues are nurtured by harmonizing emotional and rational influences}

1592f08e-0e38-4bcc-941a-c3b66cf99a23.content: {Virtue is an equilibrium between sentiment and rational judgment}, {Moral sentiments initiate moral considerations}, {Rational judgment tempers and balances the influence of sentiments}, {Virtues develop through cultivating balance between emotion and reason}

b3148a8d-3f15-4b0f-9239-44795d36ec12.summary: Virtue as Emotion and Cognitive Regulation
b3148a8d-3f15-4b0f-9239-44795d36ec12.content: {Virtue involves emotional response and cognitive regulation}, {Emotions provide the impetus for moral action}, {Cognitive processes regulate and refine emotional responses}, {Virtues emerge from the integration of emotional responses and cognitive regulation}

d1e90b32-6aa1-4e7c-83fd-3281da5202db.summary: Distinguishing between raw sentiment and cultivated virtue
d1e90b32-6aa1-4e7c-83fd-3281da5202db.content: {There is a distinction between raw moral sentiment and cultivated virtue}, {Cultivated virtue arises from moral sentiments that have been refined through reason}, {Virtue as moral sentiment involves not just feeling but a guided sentiment refined by rational processes}, {The intuition that emotions alone can lead to rash actions is due to the misunderstanding of raw sentiment as virtue}

f5fd605c-3c9b-4567-afa1-3e8b6f77aa01.summary: Rejecting the claim that emotions mislead without reason
f5fd605c-3c9b-4567-afa1-3e8b6f77aa01.content: {It is false that emotions are inherently misleading without reason}, {Moral sentiments, when properly cultivated, include an intrinsic tendency towards moral reasoning}, {The feeling of anger in the face of injustice can, when informed by virtue, lead to appropriate and effective moral action}

3bad9eb9-6960-4703-89e4-9d1630e1050e.summary: Explaining through supplementary role of moral education
3bad9eb9-6960-4703-89e4-9d1630e1050e.content: {Moral education is a necessary supplement to the development of virtue as moral sentiment}, {Moral education involves teaching how to integrate sentiment with reasoning in guiding actions}, {Once moral education is considered, moral sentiments can effectively guide moral action by themselves}

3cf461ba-0d88-4a99-9a53-c2e91cb1271c.summary: Virtue as Moral Sentiment with Practical Understanding
3cf461ba-0d88-4a99-9a53-c2e91cb1271c.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {Practical understanding is necessary for the full cultivation of virtues}, {Context-specific learning is necessary for nurturing a comprehensive set of virtues}

b4711a0a-b2a5-4ec4-917c-cf69dc4eefbc.summary: Virtue as Moral Sentiment with Cognitive Component
b4711a0a-b2a5-4ec4-917c-cf69dc4eefbc.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {A cognitive component is necessary to practically apply moral sentiments}, {Reasoning is necessary for the complete development of virtues}

a4e7b7f0-3c45-42f1-9ba9-fe8e6c942062.summary: Virtue as Moral Judgement and Sentiment
a4e7b7f0-3c45-42f1-9ba9-fe8e6c942062.content: {Virtue is a combination of moral judgement and sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Moral judgements provide a framework to interpret and apply sentiments}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments and judgements}

42952b3d-c60c-4761-b95d-b4bd445af96f.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {Practical moral skills complement sentiments for full virtue development}, {Skill development is necessary for applying sentiments to actions}

da611221-cdd9-4eec-9ce0-94b0ff831dd7.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {Context-sensitive understanding is required for proper virtue application}, {Recognizing situational nuances is necessary for virtue development}

2b066c0d-3a55-4a1a-bc4c-e5537f12a671.content: {There is a distinction between possessing a moral sentiment and knowing how to apply it in practice}, {Virtue as moral sentiment is a theory about the emotional foundations of virtue rather than the complete practical understanding}, {A person may have developed strong moral sentiments but still need guidance on their application in different contexts}, {The objection confuses the foundational role of moral sentiments with the complete development of virtues}

376d86fc-a79d-426a-9599-6f7b0d6c9f3f.content: {It is mistaken to intuit that moral sentiments alone are insufficient for cultivating virtues}, {The intuitive case assumes a misunderstanding in the practical application of moral sentiment, which does not undermine its foundational role in virtue development}, {The failure of a person to apply empathy effectively does not imply it cannot be a basis for cultivating kindness when appropriately guided}

be0b08c8-cb46-4f1a-b66a-9a419768adf9.content: {Practical wisdom is necessary to complement moral sentiments for fully developed virtues}, {The theory of virtue as moral sentiment can include the idea that cultivation involves practical wisdom for contextual understanding}, {When moral sentiments are paired with practical wisdom, they become sufficient for nurturing virtues}

8d33015c-3e4d-4026-b1d6-cfc64db72b95.summary: Virtue as a Combination of Sentiment and Practice
8d33015c-3e4d-4026-b1d6-cfc64db72b95.content: {Virtue is a combination of moral sentiment and practiced action}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are developed through habitual practice and nurturing moral sentiments}

3c8d3ab8-0f60-4064-9d00-c53a8015bcde.summary: Virtue as Sentiment Informed by Practical Reason
3c8d3ab8-0f60-4064-9d00-c53a8015bcde.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment informed by practical reason}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Practical reason provides a framework for acting on moral sentiments}

faf1acb7-ca41-44fe-a2c6-493a15e24654.summary: Virtue as Sentiment and Character Development
faf1acb7-ca41-44fe-a2c6-493a15e24654.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment coupled with character development}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Character development involves habituation and cultivation of virtues}

175a0934-588b-4872-9836-2aceeaed8ddd.summary: Virtue as Sentiment and Norm-Guided Action
175a0934-588b-4872-9836-2aceeaed8ddd.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment regulated by social norms}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through adherence to societal norms and practices}

9c5b9c2b-bbe4-4d09-b0c1-e169adc6db9b.summary: Virtue as Integrated Emotional and Rational Response
9c5b9c2b-bbe4-4d09-b0c1-e169adc6db9b.content: {Virtue is an integrated response involving moral sentiment and rational consideration}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Rational consideration helps determine appropriate actions based on moral sentiments}

0b481562-8ba8-431a-8f5f-e2ffa2dd25ac.summary: Virtue as Sentiment with Emphasis on Cultivated Disposition
0b481562-8ba8-431a-8f5f-e2ffa2dd25ac.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment emphasized through cultivated disposition}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {A cultivated disposition is developed through repeated practice and reflection on experiences}

0c70f983-ccd6-4bc8-8b3f-c7c11c1170f3.summary: Virtue as Sentiment and Empathetic Engagement
0c70f983-ccd6-4bc8-8b3f-c7c11c1170f3.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment enhanced by empathetic engagement with others}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Empathetic engagement helps refine and inform the application of moral sentiments}

ede3e31f-b8c5-44f3-8d1c-d43b1bb55dd5.summary: Virtue as Sentiment with Contextual Adaptation
ede3e31f-b8c5-44f3-8d1c-d43b1bb55dd5.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment that adapts to contextual circumstances}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Contextual adaptation involves flexible application of virtues according to situation}

7071f591-5bbe-49f7-b941-505c48036adc.summary: Distinguishing sentiment from practice and habituation
7071f591-5bbe-49f7-b941-505c48036adc.content: {There is a distinction between the role of sentiment and the role of practice and habituation in the development of virtues}, {The theory focuses on the importance of moral sentiments in motivating action, not excluding the necessity of practice and habituation}, {Moral sentiments provide the motivational basis for action, while practice and habituation contribute to the formation of stable character traits}

648ccbee-42c4-4018-8487-8db44ba59ba7.summary: Rejecting the claim that practice is separate from sentiment
648ccbee-42c4-4018-8487-8db44ba59ba7.content: {It is false that practice and habituation are wholly distinct from the nurturing of sentiments}, {The nurturing of moral sentiments inherently involves practices that engage those sentiments}, {Development through practice is an intrinsic part of nurturing moral sentiments, as it allows sentiments to be expressed and reinforced}

2f7343c4-6e9c-4f14-b9e0-90978fe15376.content: {Cultivation of virtues involves an integrated process of nurturing moral sentiments alongside practice and habituation}, {The development of virtues is not exclusively dependent on nurturing sentiments or on practice but an interaction of both}, {This integration allows for a comprehensive cultivation of virtues that engages both emotional and behavioral components}

00127f18-8147-41ab-8706-089fc9ea0df5.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {Virtues must align with universal moral standards}

fe97939b-a61d-48ea-8438-03e39d9893ca.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through integrating moral sentiments with reason}, {Reason ensures moral sentiments align with universal standards}

f0a2be3a-7536-48be-8577-fa73380aba83.summary: Virtue as Emotion and Principle Harmony
f0a2be3a-7536-48be-8577-fa73380aba83.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {Virtues manifest when moral sentiments are in harmony with ethical principles}

ee2fb391-1406-409f-b0d2-2243b215d540.summary: Virtue as Sentiment with External Validation
ee2fb391-1406-409f-b0d2-2243b215d540.content: {Virtue is a moral sentiment}, {Moral sentiments are feelings that guide moral action}, {Virtues are cultivated through nurturing moral sentiments}, {External validation is necessary to assess the alignment of moral sentiments with virtue}

b79af6ed-2b7d-4ed1-8488-1cd159313e5f.summary: Distinguishing between moral sentiments and universal moral standards
b79af6ed-2b7d-4ed1-8488-1cd159313e5f.content: {There is a distinction between personal moral sentiments and universal moral standards}, {Virtue as moral sentiment is concerned with how virtues are felt and expressed, not solely how they conform to external standards}, {A community sentiment of superiority is not a virtue if it contradicts broader principles of respect}, {The sentiment must be aligned with universal moral standards for it to be considered a virtue}

bbe8694e-8d0f-4a9b-bbb4-173fc49b19f8.summary: Rejection of the need for external standards
bbe8694e-8d0f-4a9b-bbb4-173fc49b19f8.content: {It is not necessary for virtues to be defined by external standards if they guide effective moral action}, {The priority of virtue as a moral sentiment is the internal motivation that leads to virtuous behavior}, {A community's sentiment needs to inspire actions that align with moral sentiments, not external or universal standards}

f467e3f4-1e09-422a-97fc-c727cd1028a4.content: {There is an assumption that virtuous sentiments must undergo reflective endorsement}, {Reflective endorsement means critically assessing one's own sentiments against a reflective conscience or rational deliberation}, {A sentiment of superiority may fail endorsement and hence not be considered a virtue}, {Reflective endorsement acts as a supplementary internal check that aligns sentiments with wider moral insights}

fca649c7-b5f8-41fb-b057-f787ac834a55.content: {Virtue is a rational sentiment, accessible universally}, {Moral sentiments arise from a shared rational capacity}, {Virtues are cultivated through developing rational moral sentiments}

21f2ae4c-53c3-4ecf-a306-d4a47858965b.content: {Virtue is grounded in universal moral sentiments}, {Moral sentiments that guide actions are based on objective, cross-cultural standards}, {Virtues are cultivated through aligning with objective moral standards}

87a9108c-62b4-4e34-8e2c-9fb823e1de4f.content: {Virtue stems from a common human sentiment across cultures}, {Moral sentiments are rooted in universal human experiences}, {Virtues are cultivated through recognition of shared human conditions}

ea1e268f-19b1-4686-9528-5c78dad5c848.content: {Virtue is an enlightened moral sentiment beyond cultural norms}, {Moral sentiments are formed through critical reflection on ethical principles}, {Virtues are cultivated through critical self-awareness and philosophical reflection}

864fdb92-3072-490f-9fc4-dcf38e6775f2.content: {Virtue is inherently a natural sentiment shared across humanity}, {Moral sentiments are part of human nature and inform ethical actions}, {Virtues are cultivated through understanding our natural moral instincts}

a8b07efe-5020-4a3f-89fa-c7fadc673c77.content: {Virtue is a sentiment that transcends individual cultures}, {Moral sentiments are influenced by shared cross-cultural values}, {Virtues are cultivated through engagement with diverse cultural perspectives}

ed13c57e-6646-4ffb-be11-0949324a641d.content: {There is a distinction between universal moral sentiments and contextual moral sentiments.}, {Virtue as moral sentiment depends on universal moral sentiments rather than those varying across cultures.}, {Opposing moral sentiments between cultures pertain to contextual perceptions rather than core universal sentiments.}

88d901f7-749c-438c-be9a-4869fb3bc4a2.summary: Rejecting the claim of irreconcilable moral sentiments
88d901f7-749c-438c-be9a-4869fb3bc4a2.content: {It is false that cultural differences in moral sentiments make them irreconcilable for virtue.}, {Moral sentiments can be interpreted as fundamentally shared but expressed differently due to cultural factors.}, {Cultural variations are variations in moral expression, not in the core sentiment itself.}

e695e4ac-08f6-4c51-80de-7ae5e25eb57b.summary: Explaining variations with supplementary normative principles
e695e4ac-08f6-4c51-80de-7ae5e25eb57b.content: {Virtue as moral sentiment can incorporate normative principles that are more stable than mere sentiment.}, {These normative principles provide a consistent framework for evaluating virtue across cultures.}, {Cultural differences in sentiment can be assessed and reconciled using these overarching principles.}

a93ebbe5-a63f-40b4-ab26-6764be5bbf8a.content: {Virtue is a form of moral wisdom}, {Moral wisdom involves the ability to act rightly without explicit deliberation}, {Virtue is expressed through intuitively grasping moral truths and acting accordingly}

26c7b053-c4b2-46c6-9041-cacb445ba3f5.content: {Virtue involves a sensitivity to moral emotions}, {Moral emotions guide individuals towards right action}, {Virtue requires a harmonious alignment of moral emotions with moral truths}

4faf8e0e-52a0-4b71-bfcf-8a6883e1a206.content: {Virtue is a developed disposition towards moral behavior}, {Moral dispositions are formed through habituation and practice}, {Virtue operates through ingrained tendencies to act rightly without explicit moral reasoning}

5a5d6ab1-ee17-4c0a-aa09-2ce12a5d9b7c.content: {Virtue involves understanding the moral context of actions}, {Moral understanding guides action without explicit rule-following}, {Virtue requires recognizing and responding to situational moral nuances}

d841678a-8b6a-4607-9887-fa490db925dd.content: {Virtue involves perceiving moral features of situations}, {Ethical perception directs individuals to appropriate actions}, {Virtue requires an attunement to moral saliences without relying solely on propositional knowledge}

1fe92650-d49b-42c7-9c56-6c4a66eddbf4.content: {Virtue consists of integrated moral traits}, {Moral traits work together to guide behavior}, {Virtue expresses a unified moral character that harmonizes knowledge, emotions, and dispositions}

3392ac95-547a-4030-9535-dcad00a4a132.content: {Virtue is achieved through achieving a reflective equilibrium}, {Reflective equilibrium balances moral intuitions with principles}, {Virtue requires an ongoing process of moral reflection and adjustment}

351aa436-6478-4bae-9e50-9e554807cffe.content: {Virtue involves moral skills that require practice}, {Moral skills are analogous to other forms of practical expertise}, {Virtue is demonstrated through the ability to perform morally appropriate actions skillfully}

f2f206ed-9ff6-4556-aa7e-1ae9e69d1e54.summary: Distinguishing between types of knowledge and virtue
f2f206ed-9ff6-4556-aa7e-1ae9e69d1e54.content: {There is a distinction between explicit and implicit moral knowledge.}, {Virtue involves implicit moral knowledge that may not always be articulated explicitly.}, {Implicit moral knowledge guides spontaneous virtuous actions without conscious deliberation.}, {Intellectual knowledge of moral facts alone is insufficient for virtue, which requires the integration of implicit understanding.}

e5cd155e-e20b-4825-bd70-658327f0a06d.summary: Rejecting the intuition that intellectual failure precludes virtue
e5cd155e-e20b-4825-bd70-658327f0a06d.content: {It is mistaken to think that intellectual knowledge by itself is sufficient for virtue.}, {Virtue requires not only moral knowledge but also the disposition to act on that knowledge.}, {Failures to act virtuously despite knowing what is right reflect a lack of virtue, not a problem with the concept of virtue as moral knowledge.}

34d9063d-6337-4ed3-a3cb-6a01a7fdd50f.content: {Virtue includes motivational components that compel individuals to act on moral knowledge.}, {These motivational virtues ensure that moral knowledge translates into action.}, {Even if virtue involves knowledge, it is supplemented by the capacity and will to act, explaining why some act spontaneously without explicit deliberation.}

83d4eb4d-dcd4-4af8-a848-69944d37767c.content: {Virtue involves tacit understanding of moral principles}, {Moral understanding can be implicit rather than explicit}, {Virtue can be demonstrated through consistent virtuous actions}

4bf9b42b-6ff3-4809-afb4-09909109c761.content: {Virtue is often guided by moral intuition}, {Moral intuition does not require explicit knowledge of moral truths}, {Intuitive responses can be indicative of moral knowledge}

52cf68af-a7ba-48df-bc83-c8b320879a29.content: {Virtue is based on moral dispositions}, {Dispositions do not require conscious moral reasoning}, {Virtuous actions arise from ingrained dispositions}

945db2c7-058d-4d08-879b-e0244780ee5a.content: {Virtue involves embodied moral practices}, {Embodied practices can convey moral understanding}, {Moral practices are developed through repeated virtuous actions}

16700646-c443-448b-9db6-20ff4c421b86.content: {Virtue involves practical wisdom}, {Practical wisdom is the ability to act well in varying circumstances}, {Practical wisdom does not necessitate explicit articulation of moral principles}

6c2c822a-1097-4c6b-bf4d-50092b6610f0.summary: Distinguishing between explicit and implicit moral knowledge
6c2c822a-1097-4c6b-bf4d-50092b6610f0.content: {There is a distinction between explicit and implicit moral knowledge.}, {Implicit moral knowledge is a form of understanding that does not require conscious articulation of moral principles.}, {Virtue can involve implicit moral knowledge, which allows for habitual virtuous behavior without explicit awareness.}, {The objection conflates explicit articulation of moral knowledge with the possession of moral knowledge itself.}

7135068d-341e-4da3-a813-0aa2b2469e75.summary: Rejecting the necessity of explicit articulation for virtue
7135068d-341e-4da3-a813-0aa2b2469e75.content: {It is false that virtue requires the explicit articulation of moral principles.}, {Habitual virtuous actions arise from an internalized grasp of moral truths, even if not consciously articulated.}, {A person can possess moral knowledge implicitly and act virtuously despite an inability to explain their actions verbally.}

525946dd-925d-4659-bde8-20a77f6adc95.summary: Incorporating the role of moral perception
525946dd-925d-4659-bde8-20a77f6adc95.content: {Moral perception allows individuals to intuitively grasp moral truths without explicit awareness.}, {Virtue encompasses the ability to perceive moral situations accurately, even when one cannot articulate the principles involved.}, {The importance of moral perception shows that virtue can exist without the need for explicit, conscious moral knowledge.}

b2cdc3b1-2175-4912-8896-51bf954032e0.content: {Practical wisdom involves the application of moral knowledge in concrete situations without the need for explicit articulation.}, {A person can possess practical wisdom, allowing them to act virtuously even if they cannot explicate the moral principles guiding them.}, {The concept of practical wisdom accommodates habitual virtuous behavior without requiring conscious awareness of moral truths.}

afe2a01a-9227-4f02-be37-da362a2f314a.summary: Using a supplementary assumption of moral intuition
afe2a01a-9227-4f02-be37-da362a2f314a.content: {Moral intuition involves an immediate understanding of moral truths, not requiring conscious thought.}, {The ability to act virtuously can derive from moral intuitions that guide behavior without explicit knowledge.}, {This intuition explains how individuals can consistently follow virtuous patterns without an articulated understanding.}

13f3d79c-0136-4c40-b6d6-fc203f2a9a74.content: {Virtue is a form of moral understanding}, {Moral understanding includes the ability to navigate conflicting principles}, {Virtue involves practical wisdom that allows for context-sensitive engagement with moral truths}

04fb8ee6-b5ed-4424-b7de-3f5a11ee5d69.content: {Virtue is a disposition to respond appropriately to moral situations}, {A virtuous person has a developed moral sense that informs their actions}, {This moral sense allows for appropriate action even when explicit principles conflict}

fcb9ca55-9491-4673-b9eb-fa3f1a284277.content: {Virtue consists of refined moral intuitions}, {Moral intuitions provide immediate and reliable guidance in specific situations}, {These intuitions allow virtuous individuals to discern right action despite conflicting principles}

f65e3995-b4ba-47e5-a451-3462f3437a2f.content: {Virtue involves advanced moral reasoning skills}, {Moral reasoning enables deliberation and evaluation of conflicting principles}, {Virtue incorporates reasoning to achieve clear moral discernment}

f1d38a94-535b-4e3a-914a-8dc95400dc50.content: {Virtue includes the capacity to recognize the ethical relevance of context}, {Ethical wisdom allows for adaptable responses to moral complexities}, {This adaptable wisdom grants insight into right action despite dilemmas}

e342fe42-b3ef-431e-b0b8-237d508b295e.content: {Virtue involves heightened moral sensitivity}, {Moral sensitivity enables recognition of subtle moral features in specific situations}, {This cultivation of sensitivity aids in discerning the right action amidst conflicting principles}

62a8974b-66f3-4ad5-8977-6ea4ca94a6a4.content: {Virtue is a kind of moral virtuosity}, {Moral virtuosity entails skillful navigation of moral complexities}, {This virtuosity allows for discerning right action through an artful interplay of principles}

0dab79d4-8eff-4ec6-9019-b9b7daa4e2a9.content: {Virtue embodies an integrated moral perspective}, {An integrated perspective synthesizes various moral insights}, {This synthesis aids in achieving coherence in action despite conflicting moral claims}

a52ecadc-f8d4-41a6-af75-cc05a4b48975.content: {Virtue provides holistic moral insight}, {Holistic insight encompasses understanding of interrelated moral factors}, {Virtue enables navigation of moral situations through this integrative understanding}

d3c83658-b959-4b07-965b-658974741ea9.summary: Distinguishing moral knowledge from moral application
d3c83658-b959-4b07-965b-658974741ea9.content: {There is a distinction between knowing moral truths and applying them to specific situations}, {Virtue as moral knowledge focuses on understanding moral truths, not solely their application}, {Conflicts in moral principles involve challenges in application, not in the knowledge itself}, {A failure to arrive at the same conclusion does not imply a lack of moral knowledge but differences in application skill}

115c41c7-5b28-4894-af95-b4244a76f863.summary: Rejecting the necessity of clarity in moral truths for guidance
115c41c7-5b28-4894-af95-b4244a76f863.content: {Moral knowledge does not require clear guidance in every situation to be effective}, {The presence of moral dilemmas does not entail an absence of moral knowledge}, {Reliable guidance can exist without providing absolute clarity in complex cases}, {Virtue accommodates moral complexity without needing explicit direction in all cases}

984fcf62-ef30-4e67-bfaf-bf6eb8fb081c.summary: Moral knowledge supplemented by situational awareness
984fcf62-ef30-4e67-bfaf-bf6eb8fb081c.content: {Moral knowledge provides a framework that requires situational awareness to be fully effective}, {Virtue involves integrating moral understanding with the specifics of a situation}, {Situational awareness supplements moral knowledge by informing the context}, {Varied conclusions among individuals reflect differences in situational awareness, not deficiencies in moral knowledge}

f4a78bab-c07b-472e-a592-b8914b63dcfc.content: {Virtue is a form of moral sensitivity}, {Moral sensitivity provides insight into right action}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through emotional and intuitive understanding}

f8e4f08b-6724-4c87-81db-7f1ee0ce94c9.content: {Virtue is a form of moral habit}, {Moral habit provides insight into right action through consistent practice}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through habitual good actions}

d1e7e7be-bbd2-4633-a9e3-bee990639a5c.content: {Virtue is a form of emotional intelligence}, {Emotional intelligence provides insight into right action}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through understanding and managing emotions}

45e1e2aa-85c0-496a-b688-3b0936b2cb9f.content: {Virtue is an embodied practice}, {Embodied practice provides insight into right action through lived experience}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through physical and social actions}

7f00ee00-7c8c-4f40-8ecb-95b0d4d97948.content: {Virtue is a form of empathetic understanding}, {Empathetic understanding provides insight into right action}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through empathy and compassion}

5fe40a36-fea7-463e-a200-aefa810572d3.content: {Virtue is a form of moral perception}, {Moral perception provides insight into right action}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through directly perceiving moral realities}

f6d08ef3-d9a4-415b-8635-2bab2c000ef1.content: {Virtue is a form of social intuition}, {Social intuition provides insight into right action}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through innate social awareness}

310568ac-5fbb-4136-91d5-deada904f015.content: {Virtue is a form of affective disposition}, {Affective disposition provides insight into right action}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths through feelings and attitudes}

cb4a579e-03be-4e91-9252-fb94a77e1918.summary: Distinguishing between implicit and explicit moral knowledge
cb4a579e-03be-4e91-9252-fb94a77e1918.content: {There is a distinction between implicit and explicit moral knowledge.}, {Virtue can involve implicit moral knowledge rather than explicit intellectual understanding.}, {Young children or individuals with cognitive impairments may possess implicit moral knowledge that guides their virtuous behavior.}, {Historical figures may have acted virtuously through implicit understanding of moral truths without explicit deliberation.}

9af513f8-2a61-4952-975f-5f642c240d0b.content: {Moral intuition can act as a supplementary form of moral knowledge.}, {Virtue can manifest through moral intuition even in the absence of explicit intellectual understanding.}, {Individuals may intuitively grasp moral truths through emotional or empathetic responses which guide virtuous behavior.}, {This intuitive grasp can be aligned with the possession of moral knowledge as posited by the view.}

40cf5848-b11b-459b-abf3-5594e5f929db.summary: Rejection of the necessity of deliberative understanding
40cf5848-b11b-459b-abf3-5594e5f929db.content: {It is mistaken to claim that only deliberative intellectual understanding qualifies as moral knowledge.}, {Virtue involves appreciating moral truths, which can occur without deliberation.}, {Empathy and compassion can serve as adequate bases for moral knowledge and virtuous action.}, {Virtuous individuals need not possess sophisticated moral knowledge as typically understood; instead, they may have a non-deliberative grasp of moral truths.}

542af640-dbc6-4d89-ad0a-508c25dcbfae.content: {Virtue is characterized by a consistent moral disposition}, {Consistent moral disposition aligns with moral knowledge}, {A consistent moral disposition involves predictable moral behavior}

f1d4326e-603f-410c-ab5a-7164e1a4a065.content: {Virtue involves intuitive understanding of moral principles}, {Intuitive understanding aligns with moral truths}, {Intuitive understanding of moral principles guides right action}

88682cc6-d632-42f3-a773-ad9c85130cff.content: {Virtue involves sensitivity to moral contexts}, {Sensitivity to moral contexts informs right action}, {Moral sensitivity is a kind of perceptual moral knowledge}

29f6ebe6-0b78-4e59-9355-08b711360834.content: {Virtue involves an appropriate emotional response to circumstances}, {Appropriate emotional responses align with moral values}, {Emotional responses can yield morally appropriate actions}

346729ae-6ddf-415f-bfe6-c817db596c4d.summary: Virtue as Development of Moral Character
346729ae-6ddf-415f-bfe6-c817db596c4d.content: {Virtue is developed through the cultivation of moral character}, {Moral character aligns with an understanding of moral truths}, {Moral character influences conduct in line with moral understanding}

88e2b730-a8bc-444e-94b4-8ea261767a4e.summary: Distinguishing between conscious appreciation and implicit understanding
88e2b730-a8bc-444e-94b4-8ea261767a4e.content: {There is a distinction between conscious appreciation of moral truths and implicit understanding of them}, {Virtuous behavior might arise from an implicit grasp of moral truths rather than a deliberate, conscious appreciation}, {Emotional responses and character dispositions can reflect an implicit understanding aligned with moral knowledge}

0226a7ae-7d3a-47bd-aad2-14128a342bfa.summary: Rejecting the necessity of conscious intellectual grasp
0226a7ae-7d3a-47bd-aad2-14128a342bfa.content: {It is not necessary for the intellectual grasp of moral truths to be conscious or explicit for behavior to be virtuous}, {The influence of emotions and character dispositions can align with and be guided by underlying moral knowledge}, {Virtuous behavior can result from moral knowledge manifesting through subconscious or habitual processes}

0b1c81c3-765c-4f03-8f19-5fe3958fe39b.summary: Supplementing with non-cognitive forms of moral knowledge
0b1c81c3-765c-4f03-8f19-5fe3958fe39b.content: {Moral knowledge includes non-cognitive forms such as emotional intelligence or moral sensitivity}, {Emotional responses and character dispositions can embody moral knowledge through these non-cognitive forms}, {Virtue can be understood as involving appreciation of moral truths in both cognitive and non-cognitive ways}

e0e68686-a52c-450d-a71a-cec21ce8432a.content: {Virtue is a form of practical wisdom}, {Practical wisdom balances moral knowledge with decisive action}, {Virtue involves acting rightly through the application of moral wisdom}

8ff42d9c-146c-4bc0-8a72-441d91ee5fa7.content: {Virtue is a cultivated disposition towards good action}, {Virtuous dispositions guide individuals towards right action independently of explicit moral knowledge}, {Virtue involves a tendency to act well through habitual moral actions}

e91018dc-3516-4989-8442-0c7b2ee786f8.content: {Virtue involves emotional attunement to moral situations}, {Emotional attunement facilitates immediate moral responses}, {Virtue includes the harmony of emotions with moral truths}

c6986d35-7207-4df1-8213-69587ece7b4e.content: {Virtue is a form of moral skill}, {Moral skill includes the ability to act appropriately in diverse situations}, {Virtue involves applying moral skill to navigate complex scenarios}

d518ef10-b443-432b-9422-0b701d7bb258.content: {Virtue is achieved through continuous character development}, {Character development includes integrating moral knowledge with action}, {Virtue involves progressing towards moral excellence over time}

21f2ae58-9547-4839-a46b-94c17ea0722f.content: {Virtue entails an integrative understanding of moral principles and actions}, {Integrative understanding bridges moral knowledge and practical application}, {Virtue involves synthesizing moral insight with effective action}

77663d48-9724-4809-b554-c60796206170.summary: Virtue as Balanced Rational and Emotional Response
77663d48-9724-4809-b554-c60796206170.content: {Virtue is a balanced response of rational insight and emotional awareness}, {Balanced responses align moral knowledge with emotional impulses}, {Virtue includes rationality and emotion in achieving right action}

a1500edc-08ff-43e2-97cc-1b1e09e10f0c.summary: Distinguishing between moral knowledge and moral wisdom
a1500edc-08ff-43e2-97cc-1b1e09e10f0c.content: {There is a distinction between possessing moral knowledge and exercising moral wisdom}, {Virtue entails not only knowing what is morally right but also having the practical wisdom to act on that knowledge}, {Inaction due to moral uncertainty can indicate a lack of practical wisdom rather than a detriment caused by moral knowledge}, {Moral wisdom involves the skillful application of knowledge to real-life situations to achieve virtuous outcomes}

0be638fa-bb7f-4b61-92f0-47edd971445f.summary: Rejecting the intuition that moral knowledge necessarily leads to hesitation
0be638fa-bb7f-4b61-92f0-47edd971445f.content: {It is incorrect to assume that moral knowledge inherently leads to hesitation or inaction}, {Moral knowledge is meant to guide virtuous action by clarifying the moral landscape, not complicating it}, {Instances of inaction in the face of moral uncertainty are often due to other factors, such as indecisiveness or lack of courage, rather than the burden of knowledge itself}

d3996002-d245-4df9-acd3-cad9c76a2d8b.summary: Supplementing virtue with emotional and motivational components
d3996002-d245-4df9-acd3-cad9c76a2d8b.content: {Virtue involves not only cognitive aspects like moral knowledge but also emotional and motivational components}, {Strong moral motivations can counteract any paralyzing effect of complex moral considerations}, {With appropriate emotional and motivational support, moral knowledge serves to inspire and direct virtuous action despite uncertainty}

70deb968-cfbd-40c1-8d2a-6deb25f4d45c.content: {Virtue is a quality of moral excellence}, {Moral excellence is a universal standard}, {Virtues are those qualities that align with universal standards of moral excellence}

33350bfa-b272-450b-bf19-50862c4fe5b2.content: {Virtue is a disposition to act morally correctly}, {Moral correctness is independent of social roles}, {Virtues are those dispositions that lead individuals to act morally correctly regardless of their social roles}

72e61ecd-8a15-417e-92bb-0c93a6c3ae4b.content: {Virtue is an admirable character trait}, {Admirable traits contribute to moral behavior}, {Virtues are those traits that inherently promote moral behavior in any context}

8a165374-99a7-4271-a6cd-1a6bf0a95ad2.content: {Virtue is an inherent moral quality}, {Inherent moral qualities are recognized universally}, {Virtues are those inherent qualities that lead to moral recognition universally}

967ffa36-f435-46d5-9c89-984845cd5d94.content: {Virtue is alignment with ethical principles}, {Ethical principles are universally valid}, {Virtues are those actions and qualities that consistently align with universally valid ethical principles}

9d2465da-56da-407b-aa51-c9e512593bd4.content: {Virtue is excellence in performing one's function}, {Excellence is assessed by universal standards}, {Virtues are those qualities which ensure excellence universally in any function}

8c14e777-dc5e-4ec9-b183-fb8e981ee101.content: {Virtue is integral to human flourishing}, {Human flourishing is a universal goal}, {Virtues are those qualities essential for achieving human flourishing globally}

7072d59d-1689-493d-829c-383045dd8970.content: {Virtue is an objective good}, {Objective goods apply universally}, {Virtues are those goods recognized as objectively good for all}

240d3b43-2ff6-49e7-b6dd-7b4b31b46b08.content: {Virtue is rational consistency in action}, {Rationality is a universal standard}, {Virtues are those actions consistent with universally rational behavior}

13f549da-f2d7-4695-a378-8c1ae61c0804.content: {Virtue is a form of ethical knowledge}, {Ethical knowledge is applicable in any context}, {Virtues are those aspects of ethical knowledge that apply universally}

f42510ee-b46f-41cc-80a6-a0341b12a5d9.summary: Distinguishing between universal virtues and role-specific virtues
f42510ee-b46f-41cc-80a6-a0341b12a5d9.content: {There is a distinction between universal virtues and role-specific virtues}, {Virtue as role conformity is a theory about role-specific virtues rather than universal virtues}, {Universal virtues may apply to everyone, but role-specific virtues apply to individuals based on their social roles}, {The intuition that moral virtues are universal can be explained as a conflation with universal virtues, as opposed to role-specific virtues}

71aa4475-a041-4f4b-b72a-dafe67e6e3b2.summary: Rejecting the universal application of all virtues
71aa4475-a041-4f4b-b72a-dafe67e6e3b2.content: {It is false that all moral virtues are universal and apply to all people regardless of social roles}, {Virtues can be specific to social roles and still retain moral significance in the context of those roles}, {The claim that virtues must be entirely defined by universal standards ignores the importance of context and responsibility within social roles}

33b4b2c6-dc3c-4eaf-9efe-e3131bcf10ea.summary: Supplementing with a hierarchy of virtues
33b4b2c6-dc3c-4eaf-9efe-e3131bcf10ea.content: {Some virtues are context-dependent and are derived from social roles, while others are universally applicable}, {A hierarchy of virtues can accommodate both universal and role-specific virtues}, {The appearance of equivalently virtuous actions in different roles can be explained by recognizing both hierarchical and contextual aspects of virtues}
